  • cs122b-2018-winter-project4

    v13 v14  
    4040[[Image(rotten-tomatoes.png)]]
    4141
    42 We recommend you to use a Javascript autocomplete library instead of implementing the autocomplete on your own. There are many autocomplete libraries, such as https://github.com/devbridge/jQuery-Autocomplete and http://easyautocomplete.com/
     42We recommend you use a Javascript autocomplete library instead of implementing the autocomplete on your own. There are many autocomplete libraries, such as https://github.com/devbridge/jQuery-Autocomplete and http://easyautocomplete.com/
    4343
    44 The autocomplete libraries can just satisfy the requirements or provide you a very easy way to meet the requirements:
     44The autocomplete libraries can just satisfy the requirements or provide you an easy way to meet the requirements:
    4545
     46* The user should be able to navigate the suggestions in a dropdown list using up and down arrow keys on the keyboard. During this process, when a suggested item is selected, the item should be highlighted, the text in the input box should be changed to the item's name.
    4647
    47 * The user should be able to navigate the suggestions in dropdown list using up and down arrow keys on the keyboard. During this process, when a suggested item is selected, the item should be highlighted, the text in the input box should be changed to the item's name.
    48 
    49 * Your autocomplete suggestion list need to be grouped in to 3 categories: movies, stars, and directors. See how Rotten Tomatoes search divided the suggestions into different groups (movies, celebrities, etc..): https://www.rottentomatoes.com/. You can also not group them explicitly, but indicate clearly on each item instead. See how IMDB search suggestion list shows each item as a movie or as an actor. http://www.imdb.com/
     48* Your autocomplete suggestion list needs to be grouped into 3 categories: movies, stars, and directors. See how Rotten Tomatoes search divides the suggestions into different groups (movies, celebrities, etc.). You can also choose not not group them explicitly, but indicate clearly on each item instead. See how IMDB search suggestion list shows each item as a movie or as an actor.
    5049
    5150* The autocomplete suggestion list should not have more than 10 items (the total number of items from all 3 categories).
    5251
    53 * Clicking on any of the suggestion items, or pressing "Enter" when a item is selected during keyboard navigation, should jump to:
    54   * if the item is a movie: single movie page
    55   * if the item is a star: single star page
    56   * if the item is a director: movie list page containing all the movies of this director
     52* Clicking on any of the suggestion items, or pressing "Enter" when an item is selected during keyboard navigation, should jump to:
     53  * if the item is a movie: single movie page;
     54  * if the item is a star: single star page;
     55  * if the item is a director: movie list page containing all the movies of this director.
    5756
    58 * If the user doesn't choose any of the suggestions using keyboard, and just hits "Enter" on keyboard or clicks the search button, you should do the search normally as stated above and go to the movie list page.
     57* If the user doesn't choose any of the suggestions using the keyboard, and just hits "Enter" key or clicks the search button, you should do the search normally as stated above and go to the movie-list page.
    5958
    60 * When the user types only one or two characters, you should not do any search because the results may not be helpful. You should only perform the autocomplete search when the user types in >= 3 characters.
     59* When the user types only one or two characters, you should not do any search because the results may not be helpful. You should only perform the autocomplete search when the user types in at least 3 characters.
    6160
    62 * When the user types in the query, you should not do the autocomplete search on every keystroke because the user is still typing. Moreover you don't want to send too many requests to the backend. You should set a small delay time that only perform the autocomplete search after the user stops typing for a short period of time (for example, 300 ms).
     61* When the user types in the query, you should not do the autocomplete search on every keystroke because the user is still typing. Moreover you don't want to send too many requests to the backend. You should set a small delay time (e.g., 100ms) so that that the frontend only performs the autocomplete search after the user stops typing for at least 100ms.
    6362
    64 * If the autocomplete query has been issued before, you don't want to send the request to the server again. (for example, when the user deletes some of the characters). Store the suggestion list of each query in Javascript. Everytime before your code need to do autocomplete search, first check if you can the stored suggestions, if not, then send the query to the server.
     63* If the autocomplete query has been issued before, you don't want to send the request to the server again (for example, when the user deletes some of the characters). Store the suggestion list of each query in Javascript. Every time before your code needs to do autocomplete search, first check if you can use the stored suggestions, if not, then send the query to the server.
    6564
    6665* Your autocomplete search needs to be fast. The time that user sees your autocomplete result is the delay time + the query time. Some points will be deducted if your autocomplete search takes too long.
    … …  
    6867
    6968* '''Print to the Javascript console:'''
    70   * In order to verify that your code satisfies the constraints, you need to print messages to the Javascript console. In Javascript, "console.log()" is equivalent to "System.out.println()". To see the printed messages, in Chrome, open your webpage -> right click "Inspect", then choose "Console" tab. All popular browsers have something similar, look for "Developer Tools".
     69  * In order to verify that your code satisfies the constraints, you need to print messages to the Javascript console. In Javascript, "console.log()" is equivalent to "System.out.println()" in Java. To see the printed messages, in Chrome, open your webpage -> right click "Inspect", then choose "Console" tab. All popular browsers have something similar.
    7170
    72   * We need to see the printed message when:
     71  * We need to see a printed message when:
    7372    * the autocomplete search is initiated (after the delay)
    7473    * whether the search is using cached results or sending an ajax request to the server
    … …  
    8079[[Span(id=AjaxExample)]]
    8180
    82 As a simple Ajax example, we have provided a Java-Servlet-based server program in this [attachment:AjaxTest.war  Ajax Example]. Deploy the war file to your Tomcat server. Point your browser to the link http://localhost:8080/AjaxTest/order.html. The example uses the "onChange" javascript event to trigger an Ajax communication. Type in anything in the "Item Name" input box, and move the cursor to "Time" input box, which should show the current time. Here is a [http://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/ref_eventattributes.asp complete list of Javascript events] supported by most browsers. Take a look at [http://www.w3schools.com/js/js_htmldom_events.asp this page] to learn more about how to use such events. (This example is based on the following [http://www.tizag.com/ajaxTutorial/index.php link].)
     81As a simple Ajax example, we have provided a Java-Servlet-based server program in this [attachment:AjaxTest.war Ajax Example]. Deploy the war file to your Tomcat server. Point your browser to the link http://localhost:8080/AjaxTest/order.html. The example uses the "onChange" javascript event to trigger an Ajax communication. Type in anything in the "Item Name" input box, and move the cursor to "Time" input box, which should show the current time. Here is a [http://www.w3schools.com/TAGS/ref_eventattributes.asp complete list of Javascript events] supported by most browsers. Take a look at [http://www.w3schools.com/js/js_htmldom_events.asp this page] to learn more about how to use such events. (This example is based on the following [http://www.tizag.com/ajaxTutorial/index.php link].)
